_prev_prog_2.MD_OtherType: High/low level tank level alarms to Control Room.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Specific Prevention Steps

Safety depends upon the manner in which ammonia is managed (procedures), combined with the safety control devices inherent in the design of the process. In the event of an accidental release of the regulated substance, all efforts will be made to minimize and control the release to ensure worker safety, prevent injury to the public, or damage to the environment. LSP Kendall Energy, LLC is also committed to working with the LEPC to ensure all emergency notification and response measures are effectively planned and executed.

Both active and passive mitigation systems have been developed and implemented at the Facility to reduce the potential for adverse impacts to human health and/or the environment. The controls/measures include:
* High- and low-level aqueous ammonia AST alarm
* AST safety relief valve
* AST train analysis process (once per shift)
* AST inventory control
* AST secondary containment system
* Control room monitoring of AST operating systems
* Preventative maintenance program
* Unloading process vapor recovery system
* Manned unloading operation
* Employee training in ammonia system operations
* Concrete tank saddles to prevent ground moisture contact and subsequent corrosion

The Facility's Accidental Release Prevention Program consists of the following:
* Process Safety
* Process Hazard Analysis
* Standard Operating Procedures
* Employee Training
* Mechanical Integrity
* Work Practice Safety
* Incident Investigation/Response
* Facility Auditing

All personnel handling ammonia at the Facility are instructed to be familiar with:
* Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS)
* Evacuation Procedures
* Handling Spills and Leaks
* First Aid and Rescue Procedures
* Location and Use of Firefighting Equipment
* Proper Use of Protective Clothing
* Proper U

se of Breathing Apparatus
* Location and Use of Shutoff Valves
* Location and Use of the Emergency STOP Button
* Location of Safety Showers and Eyewash Stations
* Operating Procedures
* Prearranged Procedures for Emergency Medical Care

Additionally, personnel involved with hazardous chemical delivery are instructed to review the following references:

Environmental, Health and Safety Manual Procedures:
* Chemical Management Work Plan
* Contractor Safety
* Emergency Response
* HAZWOPER
* Hazardous Material Delivery
* Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and Job Safety Analysis (JSA)

The Accidental Prevention Program of the RMP includes:

Process Safety:
Technical documentation, including process aqueous ammonia storage and SCR operating procedures have been developed to ensure safe operation of the regulated process as well as all plant operations. The process safety measures and documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, chemical inventories, and equipment design/configuration information and diagrams. MSDS are maintained at the Facility to provide chemical specific information. The electrical power generation process also uses controls and monitoring instruments to promote process safety.

Process Hazard Analysis:
The Facility has a comprehensive program to help identify and control recognized hazards associated with the regulated process. Within this program, the aqueous ammonia storage and the SCR process is systematically examined to recognized hazards and to verify that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. The process hazard analysis program is to be reviewed and updated every five (5) years, as required.

Standard Operating Procedures:
Written operating procedures for the aqueous ammonia AST system operations are in place, including system startup, normal operations, temporary operations, systeml shutdown and unloading operations, to ensure consistency of operations and reduce the potential for accidents. These procedures

are to be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. The procedures are to be periodically reviewed (how often) and certified as accurate.

Training:
To compliment the written procedures for process operations, a comprehensive employee training program has been developed for all employees involved in process operations. Training programs are designed for both new and experienced operators. New, inexperienced operators are provided basic training in plant operations. After training for new operators in complete, the new operators are to be teamed with experienced operators to learn process specific duties and tasks. After these new operators demonstrate adequate skills and knowledge of the operating requirements and safe operating practices, they are allowed to work independently. In addition, all experienced operators receive annual refresher training on operating procedures.

Mechanical Integrity:
Practices and procedures have been developed to ensure process controls, pumps and compressors, pressure relief vessels, piping systems and emergency systems are operating properly. The practices/procedures include the performance of mechanical system inspections and tests to ensure proper equipment operation and the performance of preventative maintenance. Inspection and test findings are reported to designated management personnel and corrective measures are implemented, as required, to address any identified issues in a timely manner. Maintenance personnel receive training on process operations, equipment and systems maintenance procedures, emergency response, and work practice safety to ensure that jobs are performed in a safe, consistent, and risk free manner.

Work Practice Safety:
Work practices, including entry and exit control, equipment lockout/tagout procedures (for the isolation of energy sources when required), hazardous material management procedure, hot work program, and confined space entry p

rograms, are followed to ensure safe working conditions for employees.

Incident Investigation:
All incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire or explosion, toxic gas release, property damaged (major), environmental impact, or personal injury are promptly investigated to determine the cause of the incident, evaluate response measures, and prevent future recurrence. An investigation team is to be assembled to document the investigation and its findings and recommendations. The results of any incident investigation are provided to management personnel for review and implementation, as determined. All actions taken in response to the investigation findings/recommendation are tracked until completion including any reengineering of Facility systems and/or employee task reviews.

Auditing:
The Facility will undergo a compliance audit of the accident prevention and emergency response programs to ensure adequate implementation of the programs. Audit findings and recommendations are to be provided to management personnel for review and implementation of corrective measures, as required. Any corrective measures to be implemented will be tracked by Facility personnel until completion.

In addition to the accidental release prevention measures, regulated toxic chemical specific prevention measures are also in place to help ensure proper use and safe management of aqueous ammonia and associated processes at the Facility. These chemical specific prevention measures will assist in preventing potential accident scenarios that could be caused by human error and/or equipment failures. These measures include containment system operations to help control any release of aqueous ammonia, aqueous ammonia storage system monitoring and release detection, and release mitigation measures.


Emergency Response Program

It is the policy of the LSP Kendall Energy, LLC to place the highest priority on employee health and safety and on protection of the environment and

surrounding community from any emergency conditions that may occur at the Facility. Proper emergency response planning and communication, equipment, and employee training will assist in reducing impact arising from emergency situations. 

For this reason, a written emergency response program has been established and implemented at the Facility. This program consist of procedures for responding to a hazardous substance release, including aqueous ammonia, and/or a fire or explosion. The emergency response program addresses various aspects including first-aid and medical treatment, Facility evacuation and personnel accounting, notification procedures, and post-incident cleanup and mitigation requirements. In addition, the program establishes measures for the inspection, testing, and maintenance of emergency response equipment/systems. Employees receive training in the emergency response program and procedures to perform their specific emergency response duties. The program is also updated to reflect changes in operation and/or equipment.

The overall emergency response program for the Facility is coordinated with the LEPC and the local fire department. This coordination effort includes providing the fire department with site diagrams and hazardous material information, meeting with fire department personnel to discuss Facility operations/processes, and periodic on-site inspections by fire department personnel. The Facility is also equipped with 24-hour communication system for coordination with the local police and fire department. 

If a catastrophic aqueous ammonia were to occur, site personnel would dial 9-911 which dispatches the Kendall County Emergency Services Disaster Agency. 


Worst-Case Release Scenario and Alternative Release Scenario

While a catastrophic release is not expected to occur, as required by the regulation, Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios were evaluated to estimate the potential offsite consequences (i.e., offsite consequence anal

ysis (OCA)) to the public or the environment from the potential accidental release of ammonia. 

The main objective the OCA is to determine the distance at which certain effects on the public that might occur as a result of an accidental release. The toxic endpoint concentration is defined by the USEPA as the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals can be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms that could impair an individual's ability to take protection action. The RMP toxic endpoint concentration for ammonia is 200 ppm (0.14 mg/L).

Worst-Case Release Scenario
The worst-case OCA for ammonia was performed using the Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance (April 1999) calculations. As defined under 40 CFR 68, a worst-case release of an aqueous-based substance is a ground level release of the entire tank contents, taking into account passive mitigation that would limit the release. According to the regulation, the OCA considers only the greatest amount of a regulated substance held in a single vessel even when interconnected to other vessels. At this Facility, there is only one vessel. As an administrative control, the Facility limits the maximum ammonia storage capacity to 85-percent of the AST volume. Therefore, one tank has an equivalent aqueous ammonia weight of 28,470 pounds (assuming a density of 7.44 lbs/gal) which was used in the OCA. A spill would be contained in a dike that measures 26' x 26' x 4'. Based on a dike area of 676 square feet and an assumed improbable elevated temperature of 38 degrees C (100 degrees F), the evaporation rate would be 100 pounds per minute. The Stability Class was assumed to be F (most stable), and the wind speed was assumed to be 1.5 meters per second (for a concentrated vapor plume).

Based upon the release rate, the predicted distance to the toxic endpoint concentration of 0.14 mg/L (200 ppm) is 0.6 miles

and could possibly reach up to 65 offsite public receptors.

The population within a circle with its center at the point of release and a radius determined by the distance to the endpoint was determined using the LandView III software program. This program identifies and estimates offsite receptors which include: residential populations, schools, hospitals, commercial, and industrial areas. Natural areas such as national or state parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges, or wilderness areas are considered environmental receptors and were not identified on a TOPO map of the area.

The modeled release point is located 1,200 feet west and approximately 1,500 feet south of the Facility fenceline. Using a center point of 41 28' 48.5 and -088 15' 26.2, the estimated population within this radius was determined to be 65 people by the Block Group Proration Method. Within this radius, there are no institutions (schools, hospitals, prisons), parks, or recreational areas present. Additionally, there are no environmental receptors within the radius. 


Alternative Release Scenario

The alternative release OCA for ammonia was performed using the Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance (April 1999) calculations and employing the RMP*Comp software. The alternative release scenario for the regulated process is a rupture the AST at a liquid temperature of 25 degrees C rather than the elevated temperature of 38 degrees C used in the worst-case scenario. Employing the OCA Guidance document formulas, the release rate has been estimated to be equal to 30 gallons per minute. The release was assumed to last for a 60-minute interval. Passive mitigation from the secondary containment dike was again considered. The predicted distance to the toxic endpoint concentration (200 ppm) for this scenario would not reach offsite public receptors. 

The meteorological condition assumptions are wind speed of 3 meters per second, temperature of 25 degr

ees C (77 degrees F), and relative humidity of 50%. The atmospheric stability class is assumed to be D, a neutral stability class (to represent for greater, less concentrated dispersion). Additionally, a rural [surface roughness] topography is assumed although there are buildings, walls, and other structures around the AST (therefore could be considered urban), and the release occurs at ground level. 

For the alternative-case scenario, the toxic endpoint distance was determined to be 0.10 miles (0.20kilometers) which does not leave the Facility property.


Safety Improvement Plans

The safety improvement program includes internal safety audits, which are performed on a regular basis.  RMP updates are required every 5 years or within 6 months following a revised Hazard Review, Offsite Consequence Analysis, or Program designation (§68.190). Compliance Audits are required every 3 years (§68.58). Hazard Reviews require updating at least once every 5 years (§68.50). Any Incident Investigation Summaries shall be retained for 5 years (§68.60).

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

As with any industry, there are certain inherent risks. The Kendall County Generating Facility (Facility) is taking a proactive, managed approach to risk. The Facility is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for site personnel, the community, contractors, and the environment. To meet this commitment, LSP Kendall Energy, LLC has established systems to help ensure safe operation of the process. One component of these systems is the Risk Management Program that has been established and implemented to assist in managing the risks involved with the storage and use of aqueous ammonia (>20 weight percent), the only hazardous substance stored and used at the Facility that is regulated pursuant to Program 2 of 40 CFR 68. 

To protect the environment, aqueous ammonia is used at the Facility to reduce oxides of nitrogen (NOx) pollutants, which are generated from the combustion of natural gas.  Specifically, ammonia is the reducing agent used in the Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) pollution control systems. The SCR is a post-combustion gas treatment technique that reduces nitrous oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2) in the turbine exhaust stream to molecular nitrogen and water. The SCR systems are comprised of a number of subsystems. These subsystems include the SCR reactor with associated fluework, the ammonia vaporization and injection system, and the ammonia storage and delivery system. All subsystems are equipped with the required controls and interlocks. 

The Facility is located in a sparsely populated rural area and has never had a reportable accident. Ammonia is a ubiquitous material, which is used by the surrounding farmers for fertilizer.  Pursuant to 40 CFR 68.125  Exemptions - Ammonia used as an agricultural nutrient, when held by farmers, is exempt from all provisions of this part (40 CFR 68). 

This Risk Management Plan (RMP) has identified potential hazards and has taken steps to desig

n and maintain a safe facility taking in order to prevent releases, and minimize the consequences of accidental releases which could occur. RMP addresses potentially catastrophic chemical releases that could result in immediate harm and acute health effects to offsite receptors (public and environmental). The RMP includes the Facility's Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that contains procedures, which are designed to maximize the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences. 

To foster communication with the community, the RMP and ERP have been submitted to the local fire department and the Local Emergency Response Committee (LEPC). The Facility has chosen to use a dilute solution of ammonia rather than the inherently more dangerous anhydrous form. The storage quantity of ammonia was reduced as much as possible. The storage tank area is diked and partially enclosed. The facility property is partially encompassed by a series of landscape berms, which would have a mitigating effect on an ammonia vapor plume.

At this Facility, comprehensive accidental release prevention and emergency response programs have been established. It is LSP-Kendall Energy, LLC's policy to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local rules and regulations. LSP Kendall Energy, LLC is committed to the safety of workers, contractors, and the public, as well as to the preservation of the environment. LS Kendall Energy, LLC will implement the measures necessary to prevent foreseeable releases of the substances regulated by 40 CFR 68. The measures include:

* Employee training in accidental release prevention and emergency response programs/measures;
* Establishment of safety programs for Facility operations, design, and maintenance of the regulated process; and
* Establishment of a hazard assessment process.


Five-Year Accident History

The Facility has never had a reportable accident.


The Stationary Sourc

e and Regulated Substance Handled

The Kendall County Generating Facility, located at 1401 County Line Road in Minooka, Illinois, is a 1,100-megawatt natural gas-fired combined-cycle power generating plant that includes four gas turbines, four heat recovery steam generators, and four reheat condensing steam turbines. This stationary source stores and uses a regulated substance, (>20 weight percent) aqueous ammonia (CAS No. 7664-41-7), that is used in the Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) pollution control systems. The RMP aqueous ammonia threshold quantity (TQ) limit is 20,000 pounds.  The maximum quantity of ammonia stored on site will not exceed 40,000 pounds (including all piping). The AST is centrally located within the Facility,  has a four (4)-foot high secondary containment dike, is protected by a roof and is enclosed on three sides, which would mitigate a potential ammonia release.

Nominal 30-weight percent aqueous ammonia is periodically delivered by tank truck (5000-6000 gallons) by trained qualified personnel using established standard operating and DOT procedures to an unloading station equipped with interconnecting piping connected to a single horizontally-orientated cylindrical 15,000-gallon above ground storage tank (AST). The 15,000-gallon AST volume is administratively controlled to 85-percent by volume (12,750-gallons) with an equivalent weight of 28,471 pounds reported as 28,000 pounds. The aqueous ammonia is stored at ambient temperature and will have a maximum pressure of 50 pounds per square inch-gauge (psig). 

Aqueous ammonia storage and the vaporization / injection system is the process considered for the RMP at this Facility. The largest quantity (vessel) of aqueous ammonia at the Facility is the 15,000-gallon AST. From the AST, the aqueous ammonia is transferred by pumps at a pressure of 120 psig and a maximum flow rate of 3 gallons per minute (gpm) to the vaporizers. The vaporized ammonia/air mixture is injected upstream of the SCR
